channel.title: math.HO updates on arXiv.org
channel.description: math.HO updates on the arXiv.org e-print archive.

item.title: The complexities of falling freely
item.description: arXiv:2503.17889v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Suppose you drop a coin from 10 feet above the ground. How long does it take to reach the ground? This routine exercise is well-known to every AP physics and calculus student: the answer is given by a formula that assumes constant acceleration due to gravity. But what if you ask the same question in the more realistic scenario of non-constant acceleration following an inverse square law? In this article, we explain the analysis of this realistic scenario using freshman-level calculus and examine some implications. As a bonus, we also answer the following intriguing question: Suppose the Earth were to instantaneously collapse to a mathematical point at its center. How long would it take for us surface dwellers to fall to the center?
item.dc:creator: Anindya Sen, Sunil Chebolu
